div.head: ¶ To the excellent Lady Lucie, Countesse of Bedford.
div.p: MAdam, after all the admired wits of this excellent age, which haue laboured in the sad complaintes of faire and vnfortunate Rosamond, and by the excellence of inuention, haue sounded the depth of her sundry passions: I present to your Ladiship this Epistle of hers to King Henry, whom I may rather call her louer then beloued. Heere must your Ladiship behold variablenes in resolution: woes constantly grounded: laments abruptly broken off: much confidence, no certainty, wordes begetting teares, teares confounding matter, large complaints in little papers: and many deformed cares, in one vniformed Epistell. I striue not to affect singularity, yet would faine flie imitation, and prostrate mine owne wants to other mens perfections. Your iudiciall eye must modell forth what my penne hath layd together: much would shee say to a King, much would I say to a Countesse, but that the method of my Epistle must conclude the modestie of hers: which I wish may recommend my euer vowed seruice to your honour.
